results.title: My Sweet Little Village = Vesnicko Ma Strediskova
results.creator_credit: Jan Suster, Barrandov Studios and Jiri Menzel
results.brief_description: My Sweet Little Village examines with simple affection the affairs - comic, sad, quirky and downright ordinary - of a village collective farm in Czechoslovakia. The story begins and ends with a marvellous comic pair - truckie’s offsider, Otek, and his long suffering workmate. There is not a solitary political utterance to be heard, but the film still manages to subtly convey the graft and corruption permeating every level of Czech society.

results.title: My survival as an Aboriginal
results.creator_credit: Alec Morgan, Martha Ansara, Essie Coffey and Goodgabah Productions
results.brief_description: After being forced from their tribal grounds, the Murrowarri were dumped onto a tiny reserve on the fringe of a white town. In this film Essie Coffey, black activist and musician, shows the conflicts of living as an Aboriginal under white domination. This film is part of her effort to make her community proud of their black identity while struggling to survive.

results.title: My special family
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Erin Wilson and ACMI
results.brief_description: Erin Wilson pays tribute to her special family, a family who have taught her all about life. From her family, Erin has learnt responsibility, empathy, the realities of life and death and, most importantly, love and friendship. Here she pays tribute to the members of this special family.

results.title: My sky, my home = Langitku rumahku
results.brief_description: At the centre of this film is an unlikely friendship between two twelve year old boys - Andri is from a wealthy family and Gempol is from a poor family. Both are deprived in different ways, Andri of the love and attention from his father, Gempol the chance of education and opportunities in life. A bond develops between them and they set out to find Gempol’s displaced family. The central theme focusing on the vitality and resourcefulness of the poor embellished with oblique political jokes did not find favour with it’s Indonesian distributors who withdrew it from cinemas on the grounds that it was uncommercial! The ensuing press controversy in Indonesia brought it to world wide attention. Indonesian dialogue with English subtitles. For use with secondary school students and adults, this film comes with a bibliography and study notes.

results.title: My side of the mountain. [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Robert B Radnitz, Paramount Communications and James B. Clark
results.brief_description: An edited version of the film based on children’s book by Jean George. Relates the experiences of a 13 year old boy as he learns about survival and independence in a mountain wilderness.

results.title: My shadow
results.brief_description:
Flat tyres, mystery calls. Cathy is being watched. Someone is following her, close as a shadow. Cathy tells her best friend. Heath already knows. The phone rings through the night. Is anyone listening?
A beautifully hand-drawn 2D animated narrative which captures the sense of frustration and fear when your life appears threatened by an unknown stalker and no-one out there is listening to your cries for help.

results.title: My Sesame Street Home Video
results.creator_credit: Jon Stone and Children's Television Workshop
results.brief_description: Featuring Jim Henson’s muppets and the Sesame St. live cast this series includes favorite segments from Sesame St. as well as brand new material. Each video tackles one theme, such as counting, or parties and is accompanied by a book of activities, puzzles and songs.

results.title: My People – The Presets
results.brief_description: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets, ‘My People’ (2007) was one of the biggest hits of that year, propelled by the music video from director Kris Moyes’s use of sci-fi aesthetics in the clip.

constellations_primary.name: My People
constellations_primary.description: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets, 'My People' was one of the biggest hits of 2007 and propelled by the engaging music video.

results.description: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets,’ My People’ was one of the biggest hits of that year and propelled by the music video from director Kris Moyes. The sci-fi aesthetic of the clip and their sound directly influenced The Black Eyed Peas track ‘Boom Boom Pow’ after frontman will.i.am became a fan while exposed to The Presets music during the filming of in X-Men Origins: Wolverine in Sydney, Australia.
description_for_label: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets,’ My People’ was one of the biggest hits of that year and propelled by the music video from director Kris Moyes. The sci-fi aesthetic of the clip and their sound directly influenced The Black Eyed Peas track ‘Boom Boom Pow’ after frontman will.i.am became a fan while exposed to The Presets music during the filming of in X-Men Origins: Wolverine in Sydney, Australia.

results.title: My parents don't understand me
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
Kathy Westen ran away from home at sixteen, was found six months later living rough, sleeping in derelict houses. Now she is at home again - at least for the time being. She left because she could not make her parents understand her. They worried because they could not understand what she was trying to tell them. Kathy’s act of throwing away the comforts and securities of home life represents the communication gulf between parents and their children today.

results.title: My own yard to play in
results.brief_description: Photographed on the streets of New York, this film penetrates the world children create in their play. It shows children of varying ages and different nationalities playing in the streets regardless of the life going on around them. It stresses the need for better recreational facilities for children in large metropolitan areas, and the need of a child to have a yard of its own. Production and editing by Patricia Jaffe, Larry Silk, John Schultz and Peggy Lawson.
